@nicksdjohnson @avsa I don‚Äôt see how mining power matters (but maybe I‚Äôm missing something); the second-chance-to-win is the same no matter who mines that new head.
@nicksdjohnson @avsa I‚Äôm just saying you are correct, I hadn‚Äôt considered them announcing the losing block late (after another block n is found) so it becomes an uncle in block n+1.
@nicksdjohnson @avsa Right! At height n+1...
@nicksdjohnson @avsa Ummm... the cheating miners produce alternative sibling blocks at some height n. Not uncles (siblings of the parent block at height n-1).

@avsa That's better for the miner! Less variance, because if they have any 4-of-5-numbers tickets their chances of winning a second-chance is higher!  E.g. 1-in-64 (versus 1-in-64^5 if the miner's block hash determines all 5 numbers).
@avsa This is actually no different mathematically from one miner producing all the randomness; it all depends on cost of entering, the block reward+fees, chances of winning, and amount of jackpot.

@avsa Lets say five consecutive block hashes determine those five numbers. A cheating fifth miner can see which of their entries has a chance of winning. If any do, and they produce a block that doesn't win, they can 'take another bite at the apple' by not announcing the block.

@avsa ... the number of bits of randomness from that last block doesn't matter, the math is the same. Either the lottery reward is worth throwing out a winning block hash, or it isn't, based on the jackpot and each entry's chance of winning.
@avsa Cost of throwing out the block reward: 2 ETH plus fees. So it worth it to the miner if they win more than about 2,000 ETH.

@avsa Say there are 1,000 entries, and the last miner has one of those entries. They have a 1-in-1000 chance of winning normally, but they can increase their chances to 2-in-1000 by not announcing a losing block and letting another miner get the block reward.
